an8.47:0.3: With Visākhā on the Lovable Gods
an8.47:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
an8.47:1.2: Then Visākhā, Migāra’s mother, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
an8.47:2.1: “Visākhā, when they have eight qualities females—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Lovable Host.
an8.47:2.3: Take the case of a female whose mother and father give her to a husband wanting what’s best for her, out of kindness and compassion. She would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely. …
an8.47:3.2: She lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
an8.47:3.3: When they have these eight qualities females—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Lovable Host.
an8.47:4.1: She’d never look down on her husband,
an8.47:4.2: who’s always eager to work hard,
an8.47:5.1: And a good woman never scolds her husband
an8.47:6.1: She gets up early, works tirelessly,
an8.47:7.1: A lady who fulfills these duties
